sn35.234:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca udāyī kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
sn35.234:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Udāyī were staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn35.234:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.234:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Udāyī came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn35.234:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.234:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:

sn35.234:2.1.pli: “Yatheva nu kho, āvuso ānanda, ayaṃ kāyo bhagavatā anekapariyāyena akkhāto vivaṭo pakāsito:
sn35.234:2.1.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, the Buddha has explained, opened, and illuminated in many ways how this body is not-self.

sn35.234:2.2.pli: ‘itipāyaṃ kāyo anattā’ti, sakkā evameva viññāṇaṃ pidaṃ ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññapetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ: ‘itipidaṃ viññāṇaṃ anattā’”ti?
sn35.234:2.2.eng: Is it possible to explain consciousness in the same way? To teach, assert, establish, clarify, analyze, and reveal how consciousness is not-self?”

sn35.234:3.1.pli: “Yatheva kho, āvuso udāyī, ayaṃ kāyo bhagavatā anekapariyāyena akkhāto vivaṭo pakāsito:

sn35.234:3.2.pli: ‘itipāyaṃ kāyo anattā’ti, sakkā evameva viññāṇaṃ pidaṃ ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññapetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ: ‘itipidaṃ viññāṇaṃ anattā’”ti.

sn35.234:4.1.pli: “Cakkhuñca, āvuso, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇan”ti?
sn35.234:4.1.eng: Does eye consciousness arise dependent on the eye and sights?”

sn35.234:4.3.pli: “Yo cāvuso, hetu, yo ca paccayo cakkhuviññāṇassa uppādāya, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjheyya. Api nu kho cakkhuviññāṇaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn35.234:4.3.eng: “If the cause and reason that gives rise to eye consciousness were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over, would eye consciousness still be found?”

sn35.234:4.5.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṃ vivaṭaṃ pakāsitaṃ: ‘itipidaṃ viññāṇaṃ anattā’”ti …pe….
sn35.234:4.5.eng: “In this way, too, it can be understood how consciousness is not-self.

sn35.234:5.3.pli: “Yo cāvuso, hetu yo ca paccayo jivhāviññāṇassa uppādāya, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjheyya, api nu kho jivhāviññāṇaṃ paññāyethā”ti?

sn35.234:5.5.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṃ vivaṭaṃ pakāsitaṃ: ‘itipidaṃ viññāṇaṃ anattā’”ti …pe….

sn35.234:6.1.eng: mind consciousness arise dependent on the mind and ideas?”

sn35.234:6.3.pli: “Yo cāvuso, hetu, yo ca paccayo manoviññāṇassa uppādāya, so ca hetu, so ca paccayo sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjheyya, api nu kho manoviññāṇaṃ paññāyethā”ti?
sn35.234:6.3.eng: “If the cause and reason that gives rise to mind consciousness were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over, would mind consciousness still be found?”

sn35.234:6.5.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṃ vivaṭaṃ pakāsitaṃ: ‘itipidaṃ viññāṇaṃ anattā’ti.
sn35.234:6.5.eng: “In this way, too, it can be understood how consciousness is not-self.

sn35.234:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya. So tattha passeyya mahantaṃ kadalikkhandhaṃ ujuṃ navaṃ akukkukajātaṃ. Tamenaṃ mūle chindeyya; mūle chetvā agge chindeyya; agge chetvā pattavaṭṭiṃ vinibbhujeyya. So tattha pheggumpi nādhigaccheyya, kuto sāraṃ.
sn35.234:7.1.eng: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. Wandering in search of heartwood, they’d take a sharp axe and enter a forest. There they’d see a big banana trunk, straight and young and grown unskewed. They’d cut it down at the base, cut off the root, cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths. But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.

sn35.234:7.2.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu nevattānaṃ na attaniyaṃ samanupassati.
sn35.234:7.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant sees these six fields of contact as neither self nor belonging to self.

sn35.234:7.3.pli: So evaṃ asamanupassanto na kiñci loke upādiyati.
sn35.234:7.3.eng: So seeing, they don’t grasp anything in the world.
sn35.234:7.3.comm: Editions vary as to whether the participle should be the negative form here, which would mean “so not seeing [anything as self] …”. However, in the previous line the negative is applied to the noun, “sees … not self” rather than “does not see … self”.

sn35.234:7.4.pli: Anupādiyaṃ na paritassati. Aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn35.234:7.4.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

sn35.234:7.5.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.234:7.5.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.235:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on burning.

sn35.235:1.3.eng: And what is the exposition of the teaching on burning?

sn35.235:1.4.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, tattāya ayosalākāya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya cakkhundriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ, na tveva cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
sn35.235:1.4.eng: You’d be better off mutilating your eye faculty with a red-hot iron nail, burning, blazing and glowing, than getting caught up in the features by way of the details in sights known by the eye.
sn35.235:1.4.comm: In such contexts, nimitta and anubyañjana are almost always treated as parallel synonyms. The separation of the two, with the instrumental anubyañjanaso, is found only at MN 124:20–25.1 and other late texts.

sn35.235:1.5.pli: Nimittassādagathitaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṃ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṃ kareyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati, yaṃ dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ gaccheyya—
sn35.235:1.5.eng: For if you die at a time when your consciousness is still tied to gratification in the features or details, it’s possible you’ll go to one of two destinations:

sn35.235:1.7.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṃ disvā evaṃ vadāmi.
sn35.235:1.7.eng: I speak having seen this drawback.

sn35.235:2.1.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, tiṇhena ayosaṅkunā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena sotindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ, na tveva sotaviññeyyesu saddesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
sn35.235:2.1.eng: You’d be better off mutilating your ear faculty with a sharp iron spike …

sn35.235:2.2.pli: Nimittassādagathitaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṃ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṃ kareyya, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati, yaṃ dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ gaccheyya—

sn35.235:2.4.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṃ disvā evaṃ vadāmi.

sn35.235:3.1.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, tiṇhena nakhacchedanena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena ghānindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ, na tveva ghānaviññeyyesu gandhesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
sn35.235:3.1.eng: You’d be better off mutilating your nose faculty with a sharp nail cutter …

sn35.235:3.2.pli: Nimittassādagathitaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṃ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṃ kareyya.

sn35.235:3.3.pli: Ṭhānametaṃ vijjati, yaṃ dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ gaccheyya—

sn35.235:3.5.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṃ disvā evaṃ vadāmi.

sn35.235:4.1.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, tiṇhena khurena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena jivhindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ, na tveva jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
sn35.235:4.1.eng: You’d be better off mutilating your tongue faculty with a sharp razor …

sn35.235:4.2.pli: Nimittassādagathitaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṃ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṃ kareyya.

sn35.235:4.3.pli: Ṭhānametaṃ vijjati, yaṃ dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ gaccheyya—

sn35.235:4.5.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṃ disvā evaṃ vadāmi.

sn35.235:5.1.pli: Varaṃ, bhikkhave, tiṇhāya sattiyā ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya kāyindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ, na tveva kāyaviññeyyesu phoṭṭhabbesu anubyañjanaso nimittaggāho.
sn35.235:5.1.eng: You’d be better off mutilating your body faculty with a sharp spear, burning, blazing and glowing, than getting caught up in the features by way of the details in touches known by the body.

sn35.235:5.2.pli: Nimittassādagathitaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, anubyañjanassādagathitaṃ vā tasmiñce samaye kālaṃ kareyya.
sn35.235:5.2.eng: For if you die at a time when your consciousness is still tied to gratification in the features or details, it’s possible you’ll go to one of two destinations:

sn35.235:5.3.pli: Ṭhānametaṃ vijjati, yaṃ dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ gaccheyya—

sn35.235:5.5.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavaṃ disvā evaṃ vadāmi.
sn35.235:5.5.eng: I speak having seen this drawback.

sn35.235:6.2.pli: Sottaṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, vañjhaṃ jīvitānaṃ vadāmi, aphalaṃ jīvitānaṃ vadāmi, momūhaṃ jīvitānaṃ vadāmi, na tveva tathārūpe vitakke vitakkeyya yathārūpānaṃ vitakkānaṃ vasaṃ gato saṅghaṃ bhindeyya.
sn35.235:6.2.eng: For I say that sleep is useless, fruitless, and folly for the living. But while you’re asleep you won’t fall under the sway of such thoughts that would make you create a schism in the Saṅgha.
sn35.235:6.2.comm: A schism in the Saṅgha is regarded as a heinous crime resulting in lower rebirth. It is a legal term in the Vinaya, which requires that a group of monastics who are maliciously promulgating what is against the Dhamma and Vinaya, carry out an uposatha procedure aiming to divide the Saṅgha.

sn35.235:6.3.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, vañjhaṃ jīvitānaṃ ādīnavaṃ disvā evaṃ vadāmi.
sn35.235:6.3.eng: I speak having seen this drawback.

sn35.235:7.1.pli: Tattha, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
sn35.235:7.1.eng: A learned noble disciple reflects on this:

sn35.235:7.2.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu tāva tattāya ayosalākāya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya cakkhundriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.235:7.2.eng: ‘Forget mutilating the eye faculty with a red-hot iron nail, burning, blazing and glowing!

sn35.235:7.3.eng: I’d better focus on the fact that

sn35.235:7.4.pli: iti cakkhu aniccaṃ, rūpā aniccā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ, cakkhusamphasso anicco, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ’.
sn35.235:7.4.eng: the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also impermanent.

sn35.235:8.1.pli: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena ayosaṅkunā ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena sotindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.235:8.1.eng: Forget mutilating the ear faculty with a sharp iron spike, burning, blazing and glowing!

sn35.235:8.2.eng: I’d better focus on the fact that

sn35.235:8.3.pli: iti sotaṃ aniccaṃ, saddā aniccā, sotaviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ, sotasamphasso anicco, yampidaṃ sotasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ.
sn35.235:8.3.eng: the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and ear contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on ear contact is also impermanent.

sn35.235:9.1.pli: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena nakhacchedanena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena ghānindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.235:9.1.eng: Forget mutilating the nose faculty with a sharp nail cutter, burning, blazing and glowing!

sn35.235:9.2.eng: I’d better focus on the fact that

sn35.235:9.3.pli: iti ghānaṃ aniccaṃ, gandhā aniccā, ghānaviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ, ghānasamphasso anicco, yampidaṃ ghānasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ …pe… tampi aniccaṃ.
sn35.235:9.3.eng: the nose, smells, nose consciousness, and nose contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on nose contact is also impermanent.

sn35.235:10.1.pli: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhena khurena ādittena sampajjalitena sajotibhūtena jivhindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.235:10.1.eng: Forget mutilating the tongue faculty with a sharp razor, burning, blazing and glowing!

sn35.235:10.2.eng: I’d better focus on the fact that

sn35.235:10.3.pli: iti jivhā aniccā, rasā aniccā, jivhāviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ, jivhāsamphasso anicco, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati …pe… tampi aniccaṃ.
sn35.235:10.3.eng: the tongue, tastes, tongue consciousness, and tongue contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on tongue contact is also impermanent.

sn35.235:11.1.pli: Tiṭṭhatu tāva tiṇhāya sattiyā ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya kāyindriyaṃ sampalimaṭṭhaṃ.
sn35.235:11.1.eng: Forget mutilating the body faculty with a sharp spear, burning, blazing and glowing!

sn35.235:11.2.eng: I’d better focus on the fact that

sn35.235:11.3.pli: iti kāyo anicco, phoṭṭhabbā aniccā, kāyaviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ, kāyasamphasso anicco, yampidaṃ kāyasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ …pe… tampi aniccaṃ.
sn35.235:11.3.eng: the body, touches, body consciousness, and body contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on body contact is also impermanent.

sn35.235:12.2.eng: I’d better focus on the fact that

sn35.235:12.3.pli: iti mano anicco, dhammā aniccā, manoviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ, manosamphasso anicco, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ’.
sn35.235:12.3.eng: the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also impermanent.’

sn35.235:13.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.235:13.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they become disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.235:13.2.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.235:13.2.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind … painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.235:13.3.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.235:13.3.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.235:13.4.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn35.235:13.4.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn35.235:13.5.eng: This is the exposition of the teaching on burning.”

sn35.236:0.3.eng: The Simile of Hands and Feet (1st)

sn35.236:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when there are hands, picking up and putting down are found.
sn35.236:1.1.comm: According to the doctrine of kamma, we acquire our bodies with their faculties from our desire. It does not just happen to be the case that we have hands to pick things up; we have manifested rebirth with hands because we want to pick things up.

sn35.236:1.2.eng: When there are feet, coming and going are found.

sn35.236:1.3.eng: When there are joints, contracting and extending are found.

sn35.236:1.4.eng: When there’s a belly, hunger and thirst are found.

sn35.236:1.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṃ sati cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe…
sn35.236:1.5.eng: In the same way, when there’s an eye, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by eye contact.

sn35.236:1.6.pli: jivhāya sati jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe…
sn35.236:1.6.eng: When there’s an ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.236:1.7.pli: manasmiṃ sati manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe….
sn35.236:1.7.eng: mind, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by mind contact.

sn35.236:2.1.pli: Hatthesu, bhikkhave, asati ādānanikkhepanaṃ na paññāyati;
sn35.236:2.1.eng: When there are no hands, picking up and putting down aren’t found.

sn35.236:2.2.eng: When there are no feet, coming and going aren’t found.

sn35.236:2.3.eng: When there are no joints, contracting and extending aren’t found.

sn35.236:2.4.pli: kucchismiṃ asati jighacchā pipāsā na paññāyati.
sn35.236:2.4.eng: When there’s no belly, hunger and thirst aren’t found.

sn35.236:2.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṃ asati cakkhusamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe…
sn35.236:2.5.eng: In the same way, when there’s no eye, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by eye contact.

sn35.236:2.6.eng: When there’s no ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.236:2.7.pli: manasmiṃ asati manosamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti.
sn35.236:2.7.eng: mind, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by mind contact.”

sn35.237:0.3.eng: The Simile of Hands and Feet (2nd)

sn35.237:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when there are hands, there’s picking up and putting down.

sn35.237:1.2.eng: When there are feet, there’s coming and going.

sn35.237:1.3.eng: When there are joints, there’s contracting and extending.

sn35.237:1.4.eng: When there’s a belly, there’s hunger and thirst.

sn35.237:1.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṃ sati cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe…
sn35.237:1.5.eng: In the same way, when there’s an eye, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by eye contact.

sn35.237:1.6.eng: When there’s an ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.237:1.7.pli: manasmiṃ sati manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe….
sn35.237:1.7.eng: mind, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by mind contact.

sn35.237:2.1.pli: Hatthesu, bhikkhave, asati ādānanikkhepanaṃ na hoti;
sn35.237:2.1.eng: When there are no hands, there’s no picking up and putting down.

sn35.237:2.2.eng: When there are no feet, there’s no coming and going.

sn35.237:2.3.eng: When there are no joints, there’s no contracting and extending.

sn35.237:2.4.pli: kucchismiṃ asati jighacchā pipāsā na hoti.
sn35.237:2.4.eng: When there’s no belly, there’s no hunger and thirst.

sn35.237:2.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṃ asati cakkhusamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe…
sn35.237:2.5.eng: In the same way, when there’s no eye, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by eye contact.

sn35.237:2.6.eng: When there’s no ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.237:2.7.pli: manasmiṃ asati manosamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti.
sn35.237:2.7.eng: mind, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by mind contact.”

sn35.238:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there were four venomous vipers of awesome might.
sn35.238:1.1.comm: “Viper” is āsīvisā, “venom-fang”. | Uggateja (“awesome might”) is elsewhere used of the sun (SN 2.10:5.2) or the power of wisdom (Thag 19.1:5.1).

sn35.238:1.2.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
sn35.238:1.2.eng: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

sn35.238:1.4.pli: ‘ime te, ambho purisa, cattāro āsīvisā uggatejā ghoravisā kālena kālaṃ vuṭṭhāpetabbā, kālena kālaṃ nhāpetabbā, kālena kālaṃ bhojetabbā, kālena kālaṃ saṃvesetabbā.
sn35.238:1.4.eng: ‘Mister, here are four venomous vipers of awesome might. They must be periodically picked up, washed, fed, and put to sleep.

sn35.238:1.5.pli: Yadā ca kho te, ambho purisa, imesaṃ catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ uggatejānaṃ ghoravisānaṃ aññataro vā aññataro vā kuppissati, tato tvaṃ, ambho purisa, maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi, maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ.
sn35.238:1.5.eng: But when one or other of these four venomous vipers gets angry with you, you’ll meet with death or deadly pain.

sn35.238:1.6.pli: Yaṃ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṃ taṃ karohī’ti.
sn35.238:1.6.eng: So then, worthy man, do what has to be done.’

sn35.238:2.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ uggatejānaṃ ghoravisānaṃ yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
sn35.238:2.1.eng: Then that man, terrified of those four venomous vipers, would flee this way or that.

sn35.238:2.3.pli: ‘ime kho, ambho purisa, pañca vadhakā paccatthikā piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā, yattheva naṃ passissāma tattheva jīvitā voropessāmāti.
sn35.238:2.3.eng: ‘Worthy man, there are five deadly enemies chasing you, thinking: “When we catch sight of him, we’ll murder him right there!”

sn35.238:2.4.pli: Yaṃ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṃ taṃ karohī’ti.
sn35.238:2.4.eng: So then, worthy man, do what has to be done.’

sn35.238:3.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ uggatejānaṃ ghoravisānaṃ, bhīto pañcannaṃ vadhakānaṃ paccatthikānaṃ yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
sn35.238:3.1.eng: Then that man, terrified of those four venomous vipers and those five deadly enemies, would flee this way or that.

sn35.238:3.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, ambho purisa, chaṭṭho antaracaro vadhako ukkhittāsiko piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho yattheva naṃ passissāmi tattheva siro pātessāmīti.
sn35.238:3.3.eng: ‘Worthy man, there’s a sixth hidden killer chasing you with a drawn sword, thinking: “When I catch sight of him, I’ll chop off his head right there!”

sn35.238:3.4.pli: Yaṃ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṃ taṃ karohī’ti.
sn35.238:3.4.eng: So then, worthy man, do what has to be done.’

sn35.238:4.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ uggatejānaṃ ghoravisānaṃ, bhīto pañcannaṃ vadhakānaṃ paccatthikānaṃ, bhīto chaṭṭhassa antaracarassa vadhakassa ukkhittāsikassa yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
sn35.238:4.1.eng: Then that man, terrified of those four venomous vipers and those five deadly enemies and the hidden killer, would flee this way or that.

sn35.238:4.3.pli: Yaññadeva gharaṃ paviseyya rittakaññeva paviseyya tucchakaññeva paviseyya suññakaññeva paviseyya.
sn35.238:4.3.eng: But whatever house he enters is vacant, deserted, and empty.

sn35.238:4.4.pli: Yaññadeva bhājanaṃ parimaseyya rittakaññeva parimaseyya tucchakaññeva parimaseyya suññakaññeva parimaseyya.
sn35.238:4.4.eng: And whatever vessel he touches is vacant, hollow, and empty.

sn35.238:4.6.pli: ‘idāni, ambho purisa, imaṃ suññaṃ gāmaṃ corā gāmaghātakā pavisanti.
sn35.238:4.6.eng: ‘Worthy man, there are bandits who raid villages, and they’re striking now.

sn35.238:4.7.pli: Yaṃ te, ambho purisa, karaṇīyaṃ taṃ karohī’ti.
sn35.238:4.7.eng: So then, worthy man, do what has to be done.’

sn35.238:5.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso bhīto catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ uggatejānaṃ ghoravisānaṃ, bhīto pañcannaṃ vadhakānaṃ paccatthikānaṃ, bhīto chaṭṭhassa antaracarassa vadhakassa ukkhittāsikassa, bhīto corānaṃ gāmaghātakānaṃ yena vā tena vā palāyetha.
sn35.238:5.1.eng: Then that man, terrified of those four venomous vipers and those five deadly enemies and the hidden killer and the bandits, would flee this way or that.

sn35.238:5.2.pli: So passeyya mahantaṃ udakaṇṇavaṃ orimaṃ tīraṃ sāsaṅkaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ, pārimaṃ tīraṃ khemaṃ appaṭibhayaṃ.
sn35.238:5.2.eng: He’d see a large deluge, whose near shore is dubious and perilous, while the far shore is a sanctuary free of peril.

sn35.238:5.3.pli: Na cassa nāvā santāraṇī uttarasetu vā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya.
sn35.238:5.3.eng: But there’s no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over.

sn35.238:5.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa evamassa:

sn35.238:5.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho mahāudakaṇṇavo orimaṃ tīraṃ sāsaṅkaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ, pārimaṃ tīraṃ khemaṃ appaṭibhayaṃ, natthi ca nāvā santāraṇī uttarasetu vā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya.

sn35.238:5.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā kullaṃ bandhitvā taṃ kullaṃ nissāya hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamāno sotthinā pāraṃ gaccheyyan’ti.
sn35.238:5.6.eng: ‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’

sn35.238:6.1.pli: Atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā kullaṃ bandhitvā taṃ kullaṃ nissāya hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamāno sotthinā pāraṃ gaccheyya, tiṇṇo pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇo.
sn35.238:6.1.eng: And so that man did exactly that. Having crossed over and gone to the far shore, the brahmin stands on solid ground.

sn35.238:7.1.pli: Upamā kho myāyaṃ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
sn35.238:7.1.eng: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

sn35.238:7.3.pli: cattāro āsīvisā uggatejā ghoravisāti kho, bhikkhave, catunnetaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ adhivacanaṃ—
sn35.238:7.3.eng: ‘Four venomous vipers of awesome might’ is a term for the four principal states:

sn35.238:7.4.eng: the elements of earth, water, fire, and air.

sn35.238:8.1.pli: Pañca vadhakā paccatthikāti kho, bhikkhave, pañcannetaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn35.238:8.1.eng: ‘Five deadly enemies’ is a term for the five grasping aggregates, that is:

sn35.238:8.2.eng: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn35.238:9.1.pli: Chaṭṭho antaracaro vadhako ukkhittāsikoti kho, bhikkhave, nandīrāgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn35.238:9.1.eng: ‘The sixth hidden killer with a drawn sword’ is a term for relishing and greed.

sn35.238:10.1.pli: Suñño gāmoti kho, bhikkhave, channetaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn35.238:10.1.eng: ‘Empty village’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.

sn35.238:10.2.pli: Cakkhuto cepi naṃ, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto medhāvī upaparikkhati rittakaññeva khāyati, tucchakaññeva khāyati, suññakaññeva khāyati …pe…
sn35.238:10.2.eng: If an astute, competent, clever person investigates this in relation to the eye, it appears vacant, hollow, and empty.
sn35.238:10.2.comm: Naṁ (“this”) refers back to the village; cf. SN 35.243:5.2.

sn35.238:10.3.eng: If an astute, competent, clever person investigates this in relation to the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.238:10.4.pli: manato cepi naṃ, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto medhāvī upaparikkhati rittakaññeva khāyati, tucchakaññeva khāyati, suññakaññeva khāyati.
sn35.238:10.4.eng: mind, it appears vacant, hollow, and empty.

sn35.238:11.1.pli: Corā gāmaghātakāti kho, bhikkhave, channetaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn35.238:11.1.eng: ‘Bandits who raid villages’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.

sn35.238:11.2.eng: The eye is struck by both agreeable and disagreeable sights.

sn35.238:11.7.eng: mind is struck by both agreeable and disagreeable ideas.

sn35.238:12.1.pli: Mahā udakaṇṇavoti kho, bhikkhave, catunnetaṃ oghānaṃ adhivacanaṃ—
sn35.238:12.1.eng: ‘Large deluge’ is a term for the four floods:

sn35.238:12.2.eng: the floods of sensual pleasures, desire to be reborn, views, and ignorance.

sn35.238:13.1.pli: Orimaṃ tīraṃ sāsaṅkaṃ sappaṭibhayanti kho, bhikkhave, sakkāyassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn35.238:13.1.eng: ‘The near shore that’s dubious and perilous’ is a term for substantial reality.

sn35.238:14.1.pli: Pārimaṃ tīraṃ khemaṃ appaṭibhayanti kho, bhikkhave, nibbānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn35.238:14.1.eng: ‘The far shore, a sanctuary free of peril’ is a term for extinguishment.

sn35.238:15.1.pli: Kullanti kho, bhikkhave, ariyassetaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn35.238:15.1.eng: ‘The raft’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is:

sn35.238:15.2.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn35.238:16.1.pli: Tassa hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyāmoti kho, bhikkhave, vīriyārambhassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
sn35.238:16.1.eng: ‘Paddling with hands and feet’ is a term for rousing energy.

sn35.238:17.1.pli: Tiṇṇo pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇoti kho, bhikkhave, arahato etaṃ adhivacanan”ti.
sn35.238:17.1.eng: ‘Crossed over, gone to the far shore, the brahmin stands on solid ground’ is a term for a perfected one.”
